OVERVIEW: The Palboone series consists of deep, well drained soils that formed in mixed schist, gneiss, and/or granite.  Palboone soils are on mountainsides and ridges.  Slopes range from 15 to 50 percent.  The mean annual precipitation is about 22 inches and the mean annual temperature is about 40 degrees F.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, micaceous Ustic Glossocryalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Palboone loam - forest.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise indicated.)
Oi--2 inches to 0; partially decomposed organic material mainly bark, twigs, and needles.
A--0 to 3 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) loam, very dark gray (10YR 3/1) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and slightly plastic; few fine and medium roots; many fine interstitial pores; slightly acid (pH 6.5); clear smooth boundary.  (2 to 4 inches thick)
E1--3 to 8 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) loam, brown to dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak medium and fine subangular blocky structure parting to weak fine granular; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common fine and medium roots; few fine tubular pores; slightly acid (pH 6.5); gradual smooth boundary.  (4 to 6 inches thick)
E2--8 to 19 inches; light gray (10YR 7/2) sandy loam, brown to dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak medium and fine subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few fine and medium roots; few fine tubular pores; slightly acid (pH 6.5); clear wavy boundary.  (10 to 12 inches thick)
B/E--19 to 26 inches; 60 percent brown (7.5YR 5/4) sandy loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist (Bt); 40 percent light gray (10YR 7/2), dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist (E); moderate medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few fine and medium roots; few fine tubular pores; slightly acid (pH 6.5); clear wavy boundary.  (6 to 8 inches thick)
Bt1--26 to 35 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) sandy loam, brown to dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; moderate medium and coarse angular blocky structure; hard, firm, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many thick clay films on ped faces; few medium roots; slightly acid (pH 6.5); abrupt smooth boundary.  (8 to 10 inches thick)
Bt2--35 to 50 inches; yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) sandy loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; weak coarse subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common thick clay films on ped faces; few medium roots; weak, neutral (pH 6.6); clear smooth boundary.  (14 to 16 inches thick)
Bt3--50 to 60 inches; brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) sandy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak coarse subangular blocky; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few medium roots; neutral (pH 6.6).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Douglas County, Colorado, about 1.2 miles northwest, up Roxbourg Park Road just south of Indian Creek Work Center, Sec. 3, T. 8 S., R. 69 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Mean annual summer soil temperature ranges from 43 to 46 degrees F., with an O horizon one inch or thicker.  Soil moisture regime is ustic.  These soils are noncalcareous to a depth of more than 40 inches.  Base saturation ranges from 60 to 100 percent.  Depth to the top of the argillic horizon is less than 27 inches.  Rock fragments average 5 to 20 percent in the 10 to 40 inch section.
The A horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 4 or 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist and chroma of 1 through 3.  It ranges from slightly acid to neutral.
The E horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 6 or 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist and chroma of 2 through 4.  It ranges from medium acid to neutral.
The Bt horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist and chroma of 4 through 6.  It ranges from medium acid to neutral.   It is typically sandy loam and averages 11 to 16 percent clay, 16 to 29 percent silt, and 58 to 73 percent sand.
The Cr horizon if present, is below depths of 40 inches and is mixed schist, gneiss, and granite.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  This is the Ashcroft series.  Ashcroft soils have hues of 5YR and redder.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Palboone soils are on mountainsides and ridges.  Slopes range from 15 to 50 percent.  These soils formed in mixed schist, gneiss, and/or granite.  The average annual precipitation is 19 to 24 inches.  Mean annual air temperature ranges from 39 to 43 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Security, Sphinx, and Cathedral soils.  Security soils have a paralithic contact above a depth of 40 inches.  Sphinx soils have a paralithic contact above a depth of 20 inches and Cathedral soils have a lithic contact at 20 inches or less.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium runoff; moderately rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used mainly for watershed, recreation, wildlife habitat, and timber production.  Principal native vegetation is Douglas-fir and mountain ninebark.  These soils also support scattered aspen with a grass understory.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Front Range of Colorado.  The series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Pike National Forest, East Part, Douglas County, Colorado, 1984.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  These soils have high contents of mica present which causes deception in estimations of field textures.
Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon:
Ochric epipedon - from 0 to 3 inches (A horizon)
Albic horizon - from 3 to 19 inches (E1 and E2 horizons)
Glossic horizon - from 19 to 26 inches (B/E horizon)
Argillic horizon - from 19 to 60 inches (E/B, Bt1, Bt2, and Bt3 horizons)
Particle-size control section - the zone from 26 to 46 inches (Bt1 and part of the Bt2 horizon)
The mineralogy class was changed from paramicaceous to micaceous in 07/2010 by the National Soil Survey Center on request of the responsible MLRA regional office.  The change was necessary based on the eleventh edition of the Keys to Soil Taxonomy, 2010.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
